metadata.description: Pre-composed AgentBriefingEvent payloads for Phase 1 demo

content.summary: Cedar Creek Fire: Severe burn patterns detected across 81,000 acres (63.6% high severity).
content.detail: Analysis of MTBS satellite imagery reveals 63.6% of the 127,341-acre fire perimeter experienced high-severity burn. Hills Creek drainage (SW-1) and central fire origin (CORE-1) show complete stand replacement with significant erosion risk. High severity: 81,041 acres. Moderate: 37,900 acres. Low: 8,400 acres.

suggested_actions.label: Trigger Trail Assessment
suggested_actions.description: Initiate damage inventory for trails in high-severity sectors SW-1, NW-1, CORE-1
suggested_actions.rationale: Trail network intersects all high-severity sectors; damage assessment needed before salvage access

suggested_actions.label: View Severity Map
suggested_actions.description: Display burn severity overlay on 3D terrain
suggested_actions.rationale: Visual context for severity distribution across fire perimeter

citations.excerpt: Cedar Creek Fire burn severity mosaic, accessed 2022-10-01

reasoning_chain: Analyzing MTBS burn severity classification across fire perimeter
dNBR values range from 0.22 (low) to 0.81 (high) across 8 sectors
Identifying priority areas based on severity and slope interaction
SW-1 and CORE-1 combine high severity (dNBR >0.7) with steep slopes (>35%)
Recommending immediate assessment triggers for downstream agents

content.summary: Critical trail infrastructure damage: 3 bridges destroyed, $447K in repairs needed across 40.3 miles.
content.detail: Assessment of 5 trails reveals 16 damage points including 3 complete bridge failures. Hills Creek Trail requires $238K due to primary bridge loss and debris flow burial. Waldo Lake Trail is priority 1 for visitor access. Bridge failures: Waldo Lake (40ft timber), Bobby Lake (puncheon), Hills Creek (primary). 175+ hazard trees identified. 153 crew-days needed.

suggested_actions.label: Trigger Timber Cruise
suggested_actions.description: Initiate salvage assessment for accessible high-value sectors in SW-1
suggested_actions.rationale: Hills Creek Trail repair enables salvage haul access to SW-1 priority timber

suggested_actions.label: Export TRACS Work Orders
suggested_actions.description: Generate TRACS-compatible CSV for work order submission
suggested_actions.rationale: Standardized format for district maintenance budget allocation

citations.excerpt: Trail Assessment and Condition Survey Standards, FSH 2309.18
Trail Maintenance Cost Standards FY2022, Regional Supplement R6

reasoning_chain: Correlating burn severity with trail network intersections
Hills Creek Trail traverses SW-1 (highest severity); Waldo Lake Trail crosses NW-1 and NW-2
Prioritizing based on visitor use patterns and access criticality
Waldo Lake Trail: 15,000 annual visitors; Hills Creek: salvage access route
Generating TRACS-compatible work order estimates from R6 standard rates

content.summary: Salvage opportunity: $13.9M in recoverable timber across 8,500 acres (230,350 MBF).
content.detail: Cruise data from 6 plots indicates 230,350 MBF salvageable. Plot 52-FOXTROT in SW-1 contains premium large-diameter Douglas-fir ($3,225/acre) with immediate extraction priority. Blue stain degradation requires action within 18 months. Species mix: 45% Douglas-fir, 22% Lodgepole Pine, 12% Western Redcedar. Access constraint: Hills Creek bridge repair prerequisite.

suggested_actions.label: Trigger NEPA Review
suggested_actions.description: Initiate regulatory compliance assessment for salvage EA
suggested_actions.rationale: 230,350 MBF volume requires environmental analysis pathway determination

suggested_actions.label: Export FSVeg Data
suggested_actions.description: Generate FSVeg-compatible XML for NRM upload
suggested_actions.rationale: Cruise data meets Region 6 standards; ready for timber sale package

citations.excerpt: Common Stand Exam Field Guide, FSH 2409.12
Salvage Timber Appraisal Standards, R6 Supplement 2022

reasoning_chain: Analyzing plot data for salvage value and extraction feasibility
6 plots sampled using BAF 20; extrapolated to 8,500 salvageable acres
Prioritizing by timber value, access, and time sensitivity
Large-diameter Douglas-fir degrades fastest; SW-1 has best road access post-repair
Cross-referencing trail damage: HC-001 bridge repair ($120K) enables $3.2M access

content.summary: Salvage EA pathway identified: Emergency situation determination recommended (6-month timeline).
content.detail: Analysis of FSM 2520 and 36 CFR 220.6 indicates Cedar Creek salvage qualifies for emergency situation categorical exclusion. Given $13.9M value and 18-month degradation window, recommend expedited EA. Required: Level III cultural resource survey for SW-1. Spotted owl: No known activity centers within 0.25 miles. Waldo Lake Scenic Area buffer required for NW-1 viewshed.

suggested_actions.label: Generate EA Outline
suggested_actions.description: Create draft Environmental Assessment structure with Cedar Creek context
suggested_actions.rationale: Template-based EA accelerates documentation while maintaining compliance

suggested_actions.label: View Regulatory Constraints
suggested_actions.description: Display sensitive areas and buffer zones on map
suggested_actions.rationale: Visual overlay of owl habitat, scenic viewshed, and cultural constraints

citations.excerpt: FSM 2520.4 Emergency Situations - deteriorating resource condition threshold
36 CFR 220.6(e)(6) permits salvage up to 250 acres without extraordinary circumstances

reasoning_chain: Evaluating NEPA pathway options for post-fire salvage
FSM 2520.4 establishes emergency situation criteria; Cedar Creek meets deteriorating resource threshold
36 CFR 220.6(e)(6) permits salvage up to 250 acres without extraordinary circumstances
No designated wilderness, wild & scenic rivers, or inventoried roadless areas in SW-1
Recommending hybrid approach: CE for initial 250 acres; EA for remaining 8,250 acres parallel

content.summary: Cedar Creek Recovery Synthesis: Integrated action plan ready. $120K bridge investment unlocks $13.9M salvage value.
content.detail: Cross-agent analysis complete. Critical dependency: Hills Creek bridge repair ($120K) unlocks $13.9M in salvage and enables trail restoration. Recommended sequence: 1) Emergency bridge repair, 2) Salvage CE for 250 acres, 3) Parallel EA for full project, 4) Trail restoration concurrent with salvage. Total investment: $2.55M. Projected return: 27:1 ROI. Risk: Spotted owl breeding (Feb-Jul) may delay NW access.

suggested_actions.label: Approve Recovery Plan
suggested_actions.description: Advance to detailed project planning phase
suggested_actions.rationale: All specialist agents have provided input; synthesis complete

suggested_actions.label: Export Full Briefing
suggested_actions.description: Download complete recovery analysis as PDF with maps and citations
suggested_actions.rationale: Shareable format for leadership review and stakeholder briefing

suggested_actions.label: Request Human Review
suggested_actions.description: Flag synthesis for District Ranger review before proceeding

reasoning_chain: Synthesizing outputs from 4 specialist agents
Burn severity → trail damage → timber value → regulatory pathway forms coherent narrative
Identifying cross-domain dependencies: HC-001 bridge in both trail and timber outputs
Calculating integrated ROI: trail repair enables timber access; salvage funds restoration
Time-sensitivity of 18-month salvage window drives recommended action sequence
